commentBody: Proper hard.  Liked it.
üò∞üò∞üò∞

Wow. I'm going to bed and hope my brain will be working tomorrow because right now, I'm not getting any kind of foothold on this thing. It may be the first puzzle since my streak started in January that I can't complete without lookups, but honestly, there's not even that much I can look up. Maybe I'm just tired.

At some point, I noticed the Saturday puzzles are more challenging because many of the answers are phrases, usually two words in length; knowing this makes the solution easier.
If I counted correctly, todays puzzle has 11 phrases across and 10 down..

How long did this puzzle take me? Well, Ohtani hit two home runs, one three minutes before I started, the other a minute before I finished.

Got really mixed up with vowels in the SW (PoP would be a valid response, no?). Tried brute forcing a few vowel combinations, but once I got to _EMEA, I immediately knew which consonant I needed.

This whole puzzle was nasty work. I had maybe 10% done before I hit a wall and tried playing zone. ADHOC was the brick in the wall that helped me build the grid. Once I got that, everything (slowly) started falling in place

I love taffy but my wife doesn't. It's pulling us apart.

(Well, that's kind of a stretch.)

I'd be interested in hearing an explanation for the clue to 21A:

   Crank cases?   (UFOLOGY)

Is the idea that people who believe in UFOs are eccentrics or oddballs?  I'm not convinced of their existence (yet), but if I'm interpreting the clue correctly, it seems a tad judgmental.

Got stuck a few times but kept at it. In the end, it was more difficult then usual, but all game together well.

Rings up? Clever, that one.
Only two answers after my first pass!!!  But wound up being pretty close to average time.

Well, that one really worked me over good, it was a credit to its sender, it put me through some changes, lord, WELLSORTA like a Waring blender.  (Apologies to Warren Zevon). I was definitely not on the constructor‚Äôs wave length on this one.

After half an hour I had nothing but scraps.  I was ready to pack it in and hope a night‚Äôs sleep would work its magic, but I finally got going with helpdesks. Even though that wasn‚Äôt the right answer, the help part was, well, helpful, and I gradually picked up steam after that.  Pulling TAFFYPULLS from the deepest recesses of my mind really gave me some momentum. The NW was the last to fall. I got UFOLOGY and LAURA only at the very end.  In retrospect there were a few clues that I should probably have gotten sooner, but this was a real old fashioned toughie.

Challenging but fair in my book.  Loved the way it slowly came together.  Like  @ George Stepney I only had two answers the first cut through, but one of them was wrong!  Great cluing.  Congrats to the constructor!

I for one thought this was Saturday worthy.  

Other than PDF and, weirdly, NEONTETRAS, I don't think I made a single correct entry without a cross.  Most of the longer ones I got were only partial, like I had something-BOATS for [Responders to cruise ship emergencies], but took a while to get to FIREBOATS.

As much time as I spend fearing TORNADOES, I still laughed when I got 48A.

2D gives me kind of a tingly hurt.

I thought it was a tight, challenging puzzle.
Proper Saturday crossword. I'm glad I did it online than pen on paper, lest the grid would end up illegible or torn.
Toughie! Loved it. More like this on Saturdays please.

You have to be IN AWE of the way Ohtani can SMASH a baseball.  That dude HAS GAME.

Speaking of great ... what a puzzle!

as a (non-MƒÅori) new zealander, i think it's tacky to clue FACE TAT as that. tƒÅ moko is an art form that has a lot of cultural significance (they're unique and specifically designed to tell the story of the wearer's heritage/whakapapa‚Äìthey don't even necessarily always denote rank???) and I found it jarring to see a casual phrase like that slapped onto something we grow up with knowing is sacred and extremely meaningful. don't wish to be a bleeding heart (and again, I myself am not MƒÅori) but just something to think about.
This one DESTROYED me! It took me over an hour! But I can't fault it. Mind bending clueing and solid fill. It was so troublesome I didn't even notice the repeated MAD.

This was a real challenge but a fair one. The northwest did me in, largely because I didn't know Cisco's slogan and was convinced the sauce was pomodora -- I realize now I was spelling it wrong -- instead of marinara. I'm also paying the price for having never read The Lord of the Rings.

Perfect Saturday for me. Almost exactly average time, just the right mix of fun clues, interesting facts, and a few misdirects, notably CASIO before CISCO, OPENADOOR before OPENDOORS which led me to DORITOS before OATBAR and maybe a ‚ÄîVEST before  ‚ÄîDRESS. But most people should be happy with the lack of many obscure proper names or arcane trivia, just clever interesting clues in my book and the perfect level of difficulty. The kind of puzzle you have to chew on but one that I think most people will conquer in the end.

Pleasantly and properly challenging.  A year or two ago it would have scared me more.

The center and the upper right took me quite a while. I still blanch at seeing the A word used in the NYT puzzle all the time.  It seems so unnecessarily coarse.

I had a fun time finding out how many women's names sound like letters.  First I had LN.  Nope.  Then LE.  Nope again.  LC seemed like the stretchiest but it turned out to be the winner.

Not Nab?  "Bag"?  Okay.  What kind of boat, anyway?  Nut Bar or Oat Bar.  Very chewy section.

My final fly specking pass was for Roma instead of Rome.  Some of the cluing (spirals out of control, easily removed locks) was clever.  A fun time.

I didn't like how this puzzle started right off with such a difficult and unhelpful clue at 1A.

One would have to know who the Maori are, know that they sometimes have facial tattoos, know that those facial tattoos mean something related to social rank, and know that there's an informal slang term for such a thing. That's a heavy burden for the very first answer, especially for one so long and with little to help in the crossing down clues.

This made the NW corner extremely difficult, and the overall puzzle very tedious.
Breathing heavily, but no lookups, even in the (long) checking process.
As someone who has purchased quite a lot of bread in the UK, I don't think I've ever heard the term "pan loaf" before
Jeez, BWANA crossing NEMEA left me guessing consonants - at least now I‚Äôve got two more answers in my pocket for next time. Tough one for sure!

A difficult but fair and enjoyable Saturday.

Proper nouns shouldn't cross. A bit heavy on black squares, but this was solid.

9/10
Wouldn‚Äôt HAS GAME be kinda the opposite of Can‚Äôt Hold Ones Own??

Wonderful puzzle - a welcome challenge - glad I stayed up late for it. Now that I've accomplished something satisfying, and to my mind sufficient, I can simply while away the rest of the weekend. Thank you Samuel Smalley.

A very tough puzzle. I gave up maybe seven or eight times, then some word(s) would bubble up and I pressed on.  ROSA Bonheur was there when I needed her, and pieces of fills made it look like I was making progress, so I didn't throw in the towel and do a look-up until the NW corner was hopelessly scrambled.  CISCO was the key, and I could finally stop taking LAURA out and just leave her in.  Whew. 

Grueling as it was, I thoroughly enjoyed the challenge.  Thank you, Sam Smalley. When I found that the answers were not justbsome cobbled up goofiness, I was more than ready to say YES CHEF!!  

Note:  I was sorry that "Spaniards roll them" was only four squares.  I wanted the fill to be "Ojos."
Well, I guess the average of yesterday's difficulty and today's is about right.

BWANA crossing NEMIA was pretty mean. And while I got ROMA from crossings (although theoretically a cactus AREOLe could work for the clue if you squint), doesn‚Äôt this sorta violate the ‚Äúplace names are English if the clue is in English‚Äù rule? I know the Arc is written in Italian, but ‚ÄúHome of‚Ä¶‚Äù implies an English answer, no?

These are all just fun little nitpicks. I enjoyed the workout!

One of the oddest, ‚Äî in the sense of being divorced from pretty much everything in my life to date ‚Äî and most splendid,cultural experiences I‚Äôve ever had was a day at the NY state fair in Syracuse a few years ago. 

I went there to get salt water taffy which I was introduced to by a colleague from that part of the world. So TAFFY PULLS was a very pleasant surprise. 

HELIOSTAT and NEMEA were my only anchors and LAURA later when I recalled that it was Jill Biden. The rest was hard but workable. 

Thanks to the constructor and the editors.
I really wanted 28D to be pink dolphins, was happily filling it in till the last i. Oh well, I'll settle for tetras.

This was way too difficult for me to finish without lookups and reveals. Some things I simply didn't know, like TAFFYPULLS, some I either never knew or have forgotten (LAURA... Bush?), others I was familiar with but did not understand the clue (as with RNA).

The level of difficulty of the Saturday grids presents me with a langauge and cultural barrier that I usually can't deal with on my own. But that's fine. It would be super weird if being who I am I could solve the hardest NYT puzzle of the week unaided. It does happen, albeit very rarely.

Finally! Thank you, Samuel Smalley for a hard-fought win. The mix of fill was chewy enough to make it all worth the bother . . . feeling good about earning that gold star? https://youtu.be/-DIETlxquzY?si=CJUdFNJaHdyh-sU1
Today's The Guardian has an interesting article on MƒÅori tattoos: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2025/oct/18/maori-tattoos-ta-moko-traditional-artists-new-zealand?CMP=Share_AndroidApp_Other

This was a tough but enjoyable puzzle.  I do have a problem with 2D though.  I had never heard of an aerola piercing, and while I guess they do exist, they are very rare and quite risky.  I guess the clue, site of some piercings, is valid as somewhere in the world, someone has one, but aerola would never come to mind for me.  Nipple, navel, septum, lobe and several other places that I won't mention, sure, but not aerola.
If it‚Äôs Italian, the plural is BASSI. If it‚Äôs English, the plural is BASSES. BASSOS incorrectly jumbles up two different languages.

Looks like my experience once again differed from the rest of the commenters.‚Äô It‚Äôs that rock I live under, I swear; it‚Äôs as magical as Fangorn Forest Ents. It throws a veil over my eyes when CharliXCXs and Miis pop up, but has a whole bunch of Nemeas, bwanas, Maltas, and MƒÅori face tattoos right up its sleeve. And it‚Äôs a mixture of my rock‚Äôs wizardry and my having done all the archive puzzles that sees me, a person singularly uninvested in all matters piscine, confidently fill in neon tetras from having just the ‚Äòa‚Äô in from the crosses. I‚Äôm tellin‚Äô ya: magic. 

Which is not to say I did not enjoy the puzzle, because I did‚Äîa lot. Samuel Smalley is a master of his craft. It‚Äôs not his fault that apparently a whole school of neon tetras wouldn‚Äôt stop me dead in my tracks if I stood chest-high in the Amazon. (Or would they? Any relation to piranhas? If ever there was a reason to visit Wikipedia‚Ä¶)

All in all, a really fresh and interesting Saturday puzzle. Samuel, I hope you‚Äôll grace us with another one soon. 

I‚Äôll be here under my rock, waiting. With bells on.

A tough puzzle, but I was making steady progress‚Ä¶until I hit the wall in the NE. Put the puzzle aside for a while and when I came back I TWEAKed to the solution. 

I‚Äôm amused by the number of commenters complaining about NEMEA. It seems to me that NEMEA is often in puzzles, clued as the site of Hercules‚Äô first labor. 
For those who didn‚Äôt know that Panhellenic games were played there, I encourage you to read Pindar‚Äôs victory odes. 
It‚Äôs always good to study the Classics.

Brilliant! I can‚Äôt remember when I‚Äôve confidently filled in so many wrong answers. I had gATHerS instead of FATHOMS, ELlen instead of ELSIE, nab for BAG, peanutS instead of OATBARS. And probably a few others. A long solve but very enjoyable. 

Regarding 1A, unless one is of a culture or extremely familiar with it, it seems like a good idea to avoid a reference that might be interpreted as disrespectful to that culture. I‚Äôm hopeful that the editors did a little research prior to publication.

Lots of fun words here, eg WELLSORTA, STAYSMAD, and the puzzle was definitely a good challenge.

Nitpicks: As a Brit and Great British Bake Off viewer, I can't remember anyone mentioning PANLOAF. The lower left corner, with nouns like HELIOSTAT, BWANA and NEMEA was rough.
The smallest member of the eurozone is not Malta. The google AI overview claims otherwise (!), but the smallest members are Vatican City, Monaco and San Marino (all significantly smaller than Malta).

Could not get a good start in this one so I needed LOTS of help. Still such fun. Lots of new clues/answers for me that I really liked. Thanks, Samuel! I‚Äôm sure your Mom will be proud of this one!
Happy Saturday, y‚Äôall. I hope it‚Äôs a nice one.
Thought BWANA was spelt with a U, so couldn‚Äôt see WIG, and couldn‚Äôt bring to mind NEMEA. Which I also, for some reason, think is spelt with a U. Tough corner.
Impressive all around - thanks for the workout!

Ahh, *this* is what I look forward to on a Saturday morning.  

Tricky, tricky, tricky.  

Other than uNder for IN AWE and ELlIE, then EsSIE, for ELSIE, I didn't even have that many erasures because I had no ideas.  It was all a matter of finding a foothold here and there and willing them to turn into something bigger.

Samuel Smalley made his debut in 2023 when he was 17.  Hopefully, we'll have many years of solving his creations.
Loved it! At last a Saturday that took me an hour and 20 minutes like it should!

I finished in (for me) near record time and with only very minimal help (for instance, I looked up a list of First Ladies), and expected that my ego would get slapped down after reading a slew of complaints about the puzzle being too easy, but no... apparently I just aced this one.

My RADIO SETS must be broken, because I was definitely not catching any waves. In fact, I can‚Äôt remember the last time I needed so many HELP LINES.

I have nothing to complain about, this one just wasn‚Äôt for me. But I hope Samuel‚Äôs mom is proud. (As she should be.)

Hi, Mom!

(that's for Samuel's mom)
Top tier challenge. Much, much enjoyed.

Hard but very enjoyable!
I had to go through the alphabet to get a few that were totally unknown, like TAFFEE PULLS and although I got NEON I had to get help with TETRAS. Fortunately I got the slang, like HAS GAME, from the crossers, and I looked up the painter.

I liked no actors, singers or films.
I liked OPEN DOORS, HEDGE, RADIO SETS, WIG.
Lovely jubbly.

That was really good üëèüëè 
I stayed far too long on LIFEBOAT.
As a Brit, I have to say I‚Äôve never heard of a PAN LOAF though‚Ä¶

I was surprised by the answer to 33D. Pan loaf is a type of bread in the UK? Never heard of it! A bit of research suggests it's known as a pan loaf in Scotland and Northern Ireland, which are indeed part of the UK so it's not wrong, but in most parts it would be known as a tin loaf. üçû

Whew. And Wow! Typical tough Saturday for me and a good long workout. Thirteen debut answers in this one, and... Smalley's previous puzzle (a Saturday from May 27, 2023) also had thirteen debut answers. Hmmm... But most of those answers were reasonably familiar terms. Really impressive. And.. puzzle find today - a Sunday from June 10, 1979 by the great Maura B. Jacobson with the title "Plaint speaking." All of the theme answers in that one appeared for their first and only time, but they were all familiar phrases. Those answers: IWASNTSPEEDINGOFFICER IDONTGETNORESPECT MYALARMCLOCKDIDNTRING IONLYATEONEPEANUT IDONTHAVEATHINGTOWEAR Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=6/10/1979&g=86&d=A I'm done. ...

Samuel wowed me with his debut puzzle in 2023, made at age 16, that seemed like the work of a talented pro.  I was hoping it wasn‚Äôt a one-off, that its quality would be just as good up the road.  Today‚Äôs puzzle answered my hopes with a resounding yes.

Not only is this uber-low 64-worder scrubbed of junk, it‚Äôs uber-fresh, with 13 NYT debut answers, giving us not only answers but clues we‚Äôve never seen before ‚Äì the opposite of same-old same-old.  That middle five-stack, for instance?  Three debuts and two once-befores, and all beautifully crossed.  Wow!

There were, for me, only a few no-knows, yet this fought me tooth and nail.  Battling me were vague clues with many answer possibilities, making confidently putting answers down rare and wonderful.  

There‚Äôs an art to having just enough cracks in the grid to let the light in. And that art ‚Äì at Saturday level ‚Äì was in full display today. Bravo Samuel and editors!  

I loved the debut YES CHEF, as I‚Äôm a fan of ‚ÄúThe Bear‚Äù, in which that phrase is rife.

My brain loved having its workout ethic well satisfied, and I‚Äôm thrilled by your presence in Crosslandia, Samuel.  Encores, please, and thank you!
I found this one tough. I thought for a while that I wouldn't be able to complete it but chipped away and somehow succeeded.

Only 13 minutes‚Ä¶ only 13 minutes over one hour, that is.

Just about zero crosswordese‚Ä¶ maybe ENT and PDF.

Got that good old feeling 30 minutes in of only having 5 words entered.  

Then somehow the southeast came together.  Then slow difficult progress with‚Ä¶ a surprising number of wild guesses being right, and weird memories like BWANA from some old movie that I can‚Äôt remember anything else about rising out of nowhere into my consciousness.

Northwest was last, again, couldn‚Äôt believe my desperate guesses turned out to be correct sometimes.  But as often wrong.  One thing I‚Äôve learned is to erase aggressively when no confirming cross comes pretty quickly.

Well a terrific exemplar of the best in crosswording, for me, anyway.  A repudiation of quick, obvious, impatient, flip, shallow.  An antidote to contemporary instant gratification.

But I love instant gratification too on Mondays.  Breadth is worthy.

I am just your average puzzler - don't keep track of stats, or puzzle creators, or any such - I just enjoy solving, and have for many years.  But this puzzle seems to kind of thumb its nose at ordinary solvers - I used to be able to solve Saturdays fine, but the dominance of obscure trivia now blows me away - do most people just look all that stuff up?  Looking stuff up feels like cheating to me, but guess things have changed?  No joy here today

Wrestled a bit with this one. North east corner stitched me... FIRE/LIFE.

Gripe with the Mini... well. it's not exactly mini, is it? And ORE is not the metal that miners are aiming for. Ore is the gravel / sand / rock which is dug out and which must then be refined, through crushing, sifting and chemical treatment, to extract the desired metal.
Gnarly.

This was one tough puzzle for me. First pass yielded only .pdf and a couple of other possibilities. Solving pen on paper means I have to be fairly sure before I write an answer in; my pens don't even have erasers! So I need to get a mental picture of a section of the grid before actually filling in an answer. 

After several more passes over a nearly blank puzzle, I was ready to give up. There wasn't one defining answer that got me to finish the entire puzzle, but I kept hacking away at it until finally, it was done without any lookups. Whew. Now it's 5:22 a.m. PDT, and I can go to sleep. From "No way I can do this one" to success. I'll even forgive "YES, CHEF," an answer that's meaningless to me but apparently not to others.
Proper Saturday. Thanks for the workout, Samuel!

Filled the grid but it didn‚Äôt take. Looked and looked for minutes before I remembered that ROMe and AREOLe might be incorrect. I need to remember to leave those questionable squares blank.

Fixed it, it took, I groaned.
Pretty easy Saturday, 8 minutes
Have woken up, got your coffee, nestled into your favorite spot all excited to do the Sunday puzzle . . . and then realized it's Saturday?

Today's to-do list:

1. Admire the finished puzzle ‚úÖ
2. Boast about today's finished puzzle ‚úÖ
3. Wander about, looking to find someone else to boast about today's finished puzzle to üî≤
4. Praise the author of today's *amazing, amazing, amazing* Saturday crossword ‚úÖ
5. Record a podcast about it üî≤ üòâ
Terrific puzzle!

A procedural question, please:

If one resets the puzzle, does the timer restart as well? 
And most importantly, does a puzzle reset mess with one's consecutive streak?
Fell asleep last night and my mobile didn't. Puzzle timer is now approaching 8 hours. 
Thanks in advance.

I had a small quibble with 32D - ‚Äúhaving game‚Äù means being good at seduction or flirting, or being charismatic around people you‚Äôre trying to attract. ‚ÄúHolding one‚Äôs own‚Äù felt off and made me wonder if the constructor and editors had ever used the phrase in real life üòÖ

Gah, the NE corner destroyed my streak. I won't forgive you, Samuel Smalley!

Other than my personal Waterloo, this was an enjoyable puzzle. Favorite entries: TORNADOES, TAFFY PULL, NEMEA, NEON TETRAS, HAULED patootie (bowdlerized to appease emus). More Saturdays like this please!

Overall, a refreshingly Saturday-like puzzle on this lovely Saturday (it‚Äôs gray and chilly where I am, but I assume it‚Äôs lovely somewhere).

That said: BWANA x NEMEA is a Natick if ever there was one. The *only* way around that is to observe that both of these answers have appeared in quite a few puzzles (including recent ones), and thus shouldn‚Äôt pose any problem for the good kids who have been eating their crosswordese for breakfast‚Ä¶but I still had to run the alphabet on that final ‚ÄúN‚Äù.

Some Saturday puzzles are fun and some are not. This one was a turn off for me. Obviously meant for pros. I needed a lot of help to finish it. Some of the entries were completely strange to me. Looking forward to next Saturday.
I found this to be insanely hard. Twice my average. To the person who solved this in 8 minutes: chapeau but also ‚Äî how? I found most of these clues to be indecipherable.

I always do the puzzle the night it drops, although sometimes I‚Äôm tired. And unfortunately, since Saturdays are the hardest of the week, I‚Äôm often tired for one reason or another on Friday nights. 

Such was the case last night when I took on this one. At first glance, it seemed hard even for a Saturday. 

But a few clusters of answers got me a few footholds, and when all was said and done, I finished a bit faster than my Saturday average. 

I don‚Äôt know how much of my original thought that it was a hard Saturday was the puzzle itself, and how much was my Friday night fatigue.

Second attempt:

I always do the puzzle the night it drops, although sometimes I‚Äôm tired. And unfortunately, since Saturdays are the hardest of the week, I‚Äôm often tired for one reason or another on Friday nights. Such was the case last night when I took on this one. At first glance, it seemed hard even for a Saturday. But a few clusters of answers got me a few footholds, and when all was said and done, I finished a bit faster than my Saturday average. I don‚Äôt know how much of my original thought that it was a hard Saturday was the puzzle itself, and how much was my Friday night fatigue.
Not to brag, but 7:59 is quite long for my Saturday puzzle‚Äôs comment to be posted after having hit ‚Äúsubmit‚Äù.
Tough puzzle. Travel in Greece bailed me out (Nemea).
I was briefly stuck on UFOLOGY.  I had put UROLOGY, for which I thought ‚ÄúCrank cases‚Äù was an awesome clue.  Disappointed when I saw the error.

Wow.  I just can't spend any more time on this killer puzzle.  My only claim to fame is that I got everything but the NE corner.  I could NOT get over LIFE BOATS (every ship I've traveled on required LIFE BOAT drills...)  I had TWEAKED and HEDGE (kept taking HEDGE out and putting it back.)....
...  I was never going to get OAT BARS, which I am suspicious of (as in, IS there REALLY such a thing, and if so IS IT crunchy? Maybe for the first 5 minutes; then it's not.)

I was never going to tumble to RNA for the "works in translation" and I still don't get that.  
Into every life some rain must fall, eh?  It's predicted for tonight.  PhysicsDaughter will be here to watch college football with DHubby.  I am digging out #2 of 3 stumps that are a nuisance, but I only last about 15 minutes at a time (wrists, hands) but still manage to get muddy.  (Getting dirty is good for the soul.  
Samuel, I'd be happy to help you redeem your soul; stop by any time.)

The Flamenco dancer who explained (in detail) the construction, care, and function of her MULTI-colored DRESSes was (as you can see) unforgettable.  1967.  They weren't all RED.  (She also demonstrated the castanets, while her dance partner stamped and tapped his heels.  Now, those dancers HAD GAME!)
Will....(and Sam)....c'mon. You can do better. This might be the most poorly clued crossword I've seen from NYT. Remember when Saturday crosswords were fun? Yeah, it's been a while.
I live on an island and our medical emergency transportation to the mainland is either a helicopter or our FIRE BOAT. And I still had trouble with that one.

@Caitlin Lovinger

Thanks for sharing the 50-worder!  Beautiful grid design and a surprisingly smoothe fill.

Fabulous Saturday puzzle, which nearly killed me. Solved it without any help, but it took me 50 minutes before I finally filled my last box, at the intersection of NEMEA and BWANA. Loved "Spirals out of control?" for TORNADOES. Didn't care for EBRAKE. Still, a great puzzle. More like this one, please!
Brit here. Struggled in SE corner.  NEVER EVER heard of PANLOAF. Not a thing. Sorry.
First & second run-through I thought I'd never solve, but I did it. Toughie.

Very tough puzzle even for Saturday.

Had TENORS instead of BASSOS which slowed me down

Didn't love PANLOAF or EBRAKE

Still scratching my head over the cluing for RNA and ADHOC.

Whew!
Way too hard for me and there was no door slightly left ajar to crack it open.
booooooo
Super tough one for me. Lots of clever misdirection and no real groaners. Double my average time. A+.

Sadly, 23A was not "Pull a Brodie." I can't remember the name of the movie, but it had that English actor that wasn't Michael Caine. Richard Harris, maybe? Anyway, he's driving the car being chased, and he tells his female passenger to hold on tight, because he's about to "pull a Brodie." The maneuver may have involved pulling the E-BRAKE, but the car slues around violently, and they lose the bad guys in the process.

Hour and a half for me, but eventually got the gold star with no lookups. Might be the hardest puzzle yet solved. Just a tiny glimmer of an idea in lots of places, but always a way. Giving both Sam and myself a blue ribbon on this one. Perseverance pays off

Two-thirds blank after a couple of passes and a sleep.  Even Check Puzzle didn't help.  Now I will read the column and fill in those answers.  See how far I can get with the rest before I reveal the remaining two-thirds of the puzzle.  Arrgh!

Whoa, as challenged as I‚Äôve been in a long time. Took quite a while to break open, but once it did it was a lot of fun. 

Anyone else have WILDHAIRS for [Spirals out of control]? That certainly didn‚Äôt help my SE corner!

Great Saturday puzzle!
Bwana crossing nemea is not very kind. Never heard of a panloaf

Huge missed opportunity in this puzzle‚Ä¶I am a WASP raised on Down-Home American cuisine married to an Italian-American raised entirely on his mom‚Äôs Italian cooking and maybe occasional Chinese take out. When I saw the clue for SAUCE IN ITALIAN AMERICAN CUISINE it took me back to his family‚Äôs use of the word ‚Äúgravy‚Äù‚Ä¶theirs was red‚Ä¶mine was brown, chicken, pan, red eye, etc.
I am always put off when common words like 39 A are clued as proper nouns. Also when obscure proper nouns cross to create a nattick. Not a great puzzle.
Now that‚Äôs what I come here for on Saturday! Hard, but fun and fabulously constructed. Thank you!

Took longer than my usual, a lot of taking out and putting back in. But I knew when something was finally right, even when it was completely unexpected. Such as the responders to cruise ships and what is pulled in car chases.

Who knew there are no less than three women's names that fit the clue for E_ _ IE?
